hey this is actually quite a bit um so let's just order it and of course the

so we went and took a look at the platform tried to understand how it
works what it is about and we learned very quickly on that zentry was the name of the company um an earlier company
that made a turnkey iot solution hardware and software and uh OT
management device management Etc which was later bought by silicon labs and slightly rebranded into gecko so we
learned that the juice box is probably based on this module called the WG 160p
it's a Wi-Fi module uh arm processor and it runs an a realtime operating system
called geckos and it's important to note that at the time we did this research geekos was actually end of life already
but interestingly um zentry Al also has a device management uh platform called the DMS and we found out that we could
simply register a test account there make some test products and even select different versions of geckos that they
support and once we did that we were able to download firmware blobs including the base parts of the

arrived um in our office and we started off looking for
common suspects memory corruption vulnerabilities issues with string mishandling Etc and very quickly ran
into the vulnerability that would actually form the basis of our pwn to own attempt so a bit of context around
this is that um e OS has a message logging facility it logs certain messages when certain event types occur
um these messages are based on templates and it is possible for users or applications using the API to modify
these templates you can just send a set variable command this is available through that terminal command line interface every message is limited to 32
characters including a null by Terminator so actually it's only 31 characters and it supports formatting
tags that start with an add sign and then a lowercase character um and per event type there are different potential
formatting tags that can be used but one that can be used across of all of them is at T which is replaced by a time
stamp dynamically so while looking for issues with snrf usage we quickly found
a vulnerability in the routine that formats and then logs these messages to the logging
interface looking and just zooming in on a small part of that just to highlight what the vulnerability is the routine
locates a buffer on the stack 192 bytes long and it uses that to format into it
the message that it's going to log eventually and as it goes over the template and using the data that it has
the dynamic data it goes ahead and changes every uh placeholder for the actual value that it is so looking just
at at T here to highlight what the issue is once it hits at T it goes ahead and
um generates a time stamp in a string format takes about 23 bytes using it a series of M copies and some
modifications and it does absolutely no checks whatsoever as to whether it's still within bounds of the stack
allocated buffer or it has gone out of bounds afterwards it just moves the pointer in the buffer 23 positions ahead
every single time so how could this go wrong well what if we provide multiple
atags we can provide up to 15 of them for 30 characters every one of those will use 23 bytes that's 345 bytes in
total we only have 192 bytes available on the in the buffer on the stack we're
way past this and we're into the outof bounds area we've probably overwritten Sav registers and save PC
now this had this routine had a few issues um in a few different places and
it depended on the tag but it's a bit complicated so we can't really go into it because of time constraints but we
are going to talk about it in our blog posts that will be published on our website so check them out if you're
interested in the details but back to our session title
for a second this is all happening over Wi-Fi right but we said B so what gives
well there's a secondary processor for B on the device as well that communicates with the main application processor over
SPI and it actually exposes a Serial interface more or less and it has some interface that allows a similar
interface to the command line interface that we have setting and getting variables some of these variables are
also Global OS variables and related to the application like for example the
Wi-Fi credentials so if you could communicate with a device over ble which
makes sense in the provisioning state you're using it to set Wi-Fi credentials but you can also get the pre-provisioned Wi-Fi credentials of the device but B is
turned off once the device is provisioned so how do we get that back well the answer turns out to be pretty
simple Just DE authenticated from the AP that it's connected to once you do that after a short period of time it'll fall
back into provisioning mode and you're back in B again and there you go you have it so this bug and quite a few
others were also reported in Geck OS in uh pwn to own um and the vendor has
actually um published an advisory for it since so what is the fix that they uh
offered for geckos well actually nothing because geckos is already of life so uh
the fix is no fix and this ends our foray um into the juice box and I'm

exploit for the oel Maxi charger um from all of the three
Chargers that we exploited this one had the most uh luxurious feature set so not

it has an LCD touchcreen and a rs485 port for communication between chargers
for load balancing uh and we also found out that it runs a free OS based operating

getting the firmware that took us uh quite a lot more time than actually writing these exploits
so we looked at how the uh devices
updated we found that that's mly mainly done by the mobile app so you first need
to pair a mobile app then the mobile app downloads a new firmware sends it over Bluetooth to the device so we
intercepted the traffic we thought let's just grab those URLs and download those files but it wasn't that easy so the
response that we got back from the cloud when we asked for firmare updates had a off fiscated URL so the F
info field here that's actually the URL but it has been off fiscated so we tried
for a while to see if we can like hook into the app to see how the encryption procedure
worked all turned into a mess didn't work and then we looked at it a bit more carefully we thought it looks a lot like
basic C4 but it's not correct and but then we compared we looked at what it
actually decoded and we saw that like half the characters looked correct and
then by just guessing what would the character be here and then comparing that to the actual Bas 64 we had
realized it was just something really stupid they were just replacing capital letter A with lowercase
a for a couple of different characters in seven and Y and stuff like that and that took us a couple of days to figure
out pretty embarrassing but then we could download those files
um and they were still off fiscated so we got another layer of officiation here
and as you can see by the entropy they're clearly not properly encrypted there's um if you look at them in a hexa
fi you also see patterns uh it's probably not really readable but there's a pattern that just repeats every 256
bytes here so our first guess is well it's probably aore with some 256 by key
but that just gave us garbage whatever key we tried and then we tried maybe it's addition instead of exor and that
also didn't really work out but eventually we figured out that's a combination of aor and an addition um
and we had to really puzzle to figure out basically in the same method of just guessing a few characters and then that
generates some equations that you can then later solve and eventually you have the two 2506 by keys that we could use
to get the actual firmware now this was like two days of filling in a very large
puzzle to get the actual firmb properly decrypted and then we could actually
start looking for vulnerabilities in the code so for the AEL um the pairing
process is pretty complicated the other ones you just connect over Bluetooth and you can do anything you want this one
actually has authentication um so first if you want to connect to your charger you need to
register to your account and that you do that by scanning a QR code from the manual with a serial number an 8 digit
code submitted to the Cloud Server if that charger is not yet registered and the code is correct it gives you an
authentication token and then um there's some kind of handshake with the charger where both
the charger and the app pick a random number and then they hash that together with the authentication token and the
charger says either this is correct and then you can send all Bluetooth management messages or it just uh says
it failed and it disconnects you and we're looking at this process in our
uh decompiler and we saw well this is the comparison for when the uh when it
compares the hash that it received with the hash that itself generated and it's based on B uh the authentication token
is is generated by the charger based on something like the serial number and some other tokens specific to the
charger but then we looked further in the flow of this function we saw that the same process
appears to be happening a second time but that second time it wasn't using
something that was charger specific it was using a token that was hardcoded into the firmware and it's probably not
really clear if you see the the flow like this but I'll highlight this specific message this is happens when
you use that authentication token in the uh firmware and they say o BD suck now I
don't really know for sure what BD stands for but we think they just intended this as a back door um in their
Bluetooth authentication functionality so once you have connected
to the charger there's quite a lot of manage messages you can send you can basically manage the entire charger over

out immediately because uh there was a stack based buffer overflow there's a specific message um
we're not sure exactly what it's used for but it's some charging control parameters as you can see at the bottom
um but if you send that message the entire Bluetooth message is copied into a 60 by Stack buffer without verifying
the length so that message can be any size it can be many many times more than
those 60 bytes um and with this you're just directly overflowing the
stack and similar to the juice box there are no mitigations here there's no staries there's no aslr you're not

think writing this exploit took us only like a morning all three of us working on this together the the only bit of a
tricky part here is that because it's an Aros uh you cannot just exit the process
um because then the entire thing crashes there's no processes so you need to properly clean up everything and make

everything continued properly so we had found this and we moved on to other targets because we
still had other uh things we hadn't hacked yet but then um as the

its websockets over an https connection and they are decoded Json and in this

checks and we're lot happier with this bug because it's a lot more subtle you need to change the ocpp connection

days now we get a lot asked a lot about what is the impact of hacking EV
Chargers and there's basically two main things you could do if you hack a
charger um what we saw in the design in internal design of all of the three Chargers is that the connectivity module
is separate from the power controller so there's something handling Wi-Fi and something handling the actual charging
process and that one handles like the limit current the over it checks the
temperature and it starts throttling if it gets too hot and if you could modify that firmware you could actually damage
the charger because of the safety checks and at least for the AEL we know
that this firmware can actually also be updated so the power controller can be updated from the other chip that we
hacked there's no signatures nothing like that if we just push out a malicious update it just disables all
safety checks we can push it to the charger and then it no longer shuts down when it overheats
secondly the if you have a charger with payment functionality you could also hack it in order to charge for free or

functionality um because one what these Chargers like this it's actually only
the charger that determines how much money you will be be built for because the car doesn't really know anything

provider and the charging card itself cannot communicate so it's just the charger that knows how much how much you

makes the level of vulnerabilities that we saw here pretty worrying
and finally I'm going to give it to khet for some takeaways
you so throughout our work with um EV Chargers as well as iot devices in
